title: Evening recap
summary:
Evening recap

Our live blog will shortly be closing until tomorrow morning.

Here are the day's key developments:

  • The London Metropolitan Police used batons to disperse peaceful protestors and arrested dozens of demonstrators calling on the UK government to reverse its decision to designate Palestine Action as a terrorist group. 

  • "The Voice of Hind Rajab" won the Silver Lion grand jury prize at the Venice Film Festival.  

  • Save the Children says that on average at least one Palestinian child has been killed every hour in Gaza during nearly 23 months of war.

  • At least 67 people have been killed by Israel since the early hours of this morning, according to Al Jazeera, citing sources at local hospitals.

  • One of defence company Elbit Systems' plants in the UK city of Bristol has reportedly been closed in the wake of a Palestine Action campaign, according to The Guardian.

  • Six Palestinians, including a child, died in the past 24 hours from starvation and malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, Wafa news agency reported, citing medical sources.

  • The United States has placed three leading Palestinian rights organisations â€“ Al-Haq, the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights (PCHR), and Al Mezan â€“ on its sanctions list. 

  • The Israeli military has destroyed more than seventy percent of the buildings in Gaza City, according to Al Jazeera, citing local reports.

title: Israeli protesters call on Trump to end Gaza war
summary:
Israeli protesters call on Trump to end Gaza war

Thousands of Israelis rallied in Tel Aviv on Saturday night, issuing direct appeals to US President Donald Trump to force an end to the war on Gaza and secure the release of the captives.

Protesters packed a public square outside the military headquarters, waving Israeli flags and holding placards with images of the captives. Some carried signs, including one that read: 'Trumpâ€™s legacy crumbles as the Gaza war persists'.

"We think that Trump is the only man in the world who has authority over Bibi, that can force Bibi to do this," said Tel Aviv resident Boaz, 40, referring to the Israeli prime minister.

Orna Neutra, the mother of an Israeli soldier who was killed on 7 October, 2023, and whose body is being held in Gaza, accused the government of abandoning its citizens.

â€œWe truly hope that the United States will push both sides to finally reach a comprehensive deal that will bring them home,â€ she told the rally. Her son, Omer, is also American.

title: Report: Israeli army destroys more than seventy percent of Gaza City buildings
summary:
Report: Israeli army destroys more than seventy percent of Gaza City buildings

The Israeli military has destroyed more than seventy percent of the buildings in Gaza City, according to Al Jazeera, citing local reports.

Meanwhile, Haaretz is reporting that the Israeli military claimed that the Soussi Tower in Gaza City was used by Hamas and acknowledged targeting it today. Hamas denies the Israeli claims.

title: Gaza aid flotilla from Tunisia delayed
summary:
Gaza aid flotilla from Tunisia delayed

The departure from Tunisia of pro-Palestinian activists seeking to break Israel's naval blockade of Gaza with aid boats has been postponed, organisers said on Saturday.

It was planned for Sunday, but organisers said they rescheduled the boats' departure from Tunis to Wednesday, 10 September, due to "technical and logistical reasons beyond management's control".

The Maghreb Sumud Flotilla, which aimed to join boats of the Global Sumud Flotilla that have already left from Spain and Italy, had already been delayed by bad weather.

Crowds in Tunis gather with unstoppable spirit to join the #GlobalSumudFlotilla on its journey to break the siege on Gaza

ğŸ“· alhelou.y (IG) pic.twitter.com/2TWIUpezbA

â€” Global Sumud Flotilla (@GlobalSumudFlot) September 6, 2025

title: Gaza death toll rises
summary:
Gaza death toll rises

At least 67 people have been killed by Israel since the early hours of this morning, according to Al Jazeera, citing sources at local hospitals.

The majority of these people, 45, were killed in Gaza City, as the Israeli army continues its campaign to seize the city and forcefully displace all its residents south.

title: 'The Voice of Hind Rajab' wins second prize at Venice Film Festival
summary:
'The Voice of Hind Rajab' wins second prize at Venice Film Festival

"The Voice of Hind Rajab", a gut-wrenching Gaza film that left audiences sobbing at its premiere, won the Silver Lion grand jury prize at the Venice Film Festival on Saturday.  

The movie, from French-Tunisian director Kaouther Ben Hania, is about the real-life killing of five-year-old Palestinian girl Hind Rajab by Israeli forces while her family was trying to flee Gaza. 

An investigation found that the car in which Rajab was killed had been hit with 335 bullets.

She was found dead on 10 February 2024 in northern Gaza, after nearly two weeks of being trapped inside a car with her family while being surrounded by Israeli military forces and being subject to Israeli fire.

title: Egypt says describing displacement of Palestinians as voluntary is 'nonsense'
summary:
Egypt says describing displacement of Palestinians as voluntary is 'nonsense'

Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty, whose country is a key mediator in efforts to end Israel's war on Gaza, said on Saturday that describing the displacement of Palestinians as voluntary was "nonsense".

Israel earlier called on Gaza City residents to leave for the south, as its forces advance deeper into the enclaveâ€™s largest urban area.

"If there is a manmade famine (in Gaza), it is to push residents out of their land. It is nonsense to say that this is voluntary displacement," Abdelatty said in a joint press conference with the commissioner-general of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, Philippe Lazzarini.

title: Report: Israeli forces kill Palestinian man who threw water bottle on road
summary:
Report: Israeli forces kill Palestinian man who threw water bottle on road

Israeli soldiers killed a 57-year-old Palestinian man as he threw a water bottle on the road at the Al-Murabaâ€™ah checkpoint, south of Nablus in the occupied West Bank, according to activists.

Reporting the killing, the Israeli activist group Mistaclim identified the victim as Ahmed Abd al-Fatah Shehadeh.

Al-Murabaâ€™ah checkpoint, south of Nablus. A resident of the village Urif, Ahmed Abd al-Fatah Shehadeh, 57, threw a water bottle on the road and was shot dead by soldiers.

Soldiers killed a 57-year-old Palestinian who threw a water bottle on the ground.

title: Unrwa chief says Gaza 'manmade famine' can be reversed
summary:
Unrwa chief says Gaza 'manmade famine' can be reversed

Unrwa Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini said total impunity and lack of empathy have made life for Palestinians in Gaza "an inferno."

In a post on X, Lazzarini said the latest plague is a "manmade famine" and "it can be reversed."

"All it takes to change course is political will, open the gates & let us work," he said, adding that Unrwa alone has enough food and assistance currently stuck in Egypt and Jordan to cover the critical needs of the entire population for three months.

Total impunity & lack of empathy have made life for Gazans an inferno.

The latest plague is a manmade #famine. It can be reversed : all it takes to change course is political will, open the gates & let us work.

In Cairo today, I called again for an immediate #ceasefire toâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/tlLrBaUCiT

â€” Philippe Lazzarini (@UNLazzarini) September 6, 2025

title: Israel kills 60 Palestinians in last 24 hours
summary:
Israel kills 60 Palestinians in last 24 hours

At least 58 people, including  16 aid seekers, have been killed by Israeli forces on Saturday, according to Al Jazeera, citing hospital sources in the Strip.

The sources said 37 people were killed in Gaza City and the northern Gaza Strip,

Hamad Hospital said 70 aid seekers were wounded by Israeli army fire in the northern Gaza Strip.

title: Arrests made at demonstration against Palestine Action proscription in London
summary:
Arrests made at demonstration against Palestine Action proscription in London

Police in London have arrested protesters calling for Palestine Action to have its proscription as a terrorist group repealed.

Hundreds had gathered in Westminster's Parliament Square holding placards reading "I support Palestine Action" and opposing Israel's ongoing genocide in Gaza.

â€œOfficers have begun making arrests for expressing support for proscribed terror organisation Palestine Action at the protest organised by Defend Our Juries," the Metropolitan Police said in a statement.

Defend Our Juries (DOJ), which has staged regular protests since the government moved to proscribe Palestine Action in July, told protesters who signed up for Saturdayâ€™s demonstration to withhold their details from officers to force mass processing at police stations.

The group had scheduled a press conference on Tuesday to announce that an estimated 1,500 people were going to risk arrest under the Terrorism Act for holding signs reading, â€œI oppose genocide. I support Palestine Action.â€

Read more: Arrests made at demonstration against Palestine Action proscription in London

title: Police use batons as dozens arrested at Palestine Action protest
summary:
Police use batons as dozens arrested at Palestine Action protest

Submitted by Areeb Ullah on Sat, 09/06/2025 - 16:59
Elderly demonstrators and families of Holocaust survivors were among those detained in Parliament Square
An elderly protester is taken away by police officers at a "Lift The Ban" demonstration in support of the proscribed group Palestine Action, calling for the recently imposed ban to be lifted, in Parliament Square, central London, on September 6, 2025.
Off

The London Metropolitan Police used batons to disperse peaceful protestors and arrested dozens of demonstrators calling on the UK government to reverse its decision to designate Palestine Action as a terrorist group. 

Hundreds had gathered in Westminster's Parliament Square on Saturday, holding cardboard placards reading "I support Palestine Action" and flags in support of Palestine. 

Officers surrounded protestors and carried them one by one to waiting vans, with an officer holding each limb, as crowds chanted "shame on you." 

Some of those facing arrest stayed silent, while others chanted "free Palestine" and urged officers not to follow orders and let them go.

Middle East Eye also saw officers reading out a pre-prepared statement to protestors they were arresting, stating that they were detaining them on "suspicion that you are a member or supporter of the proscribed group Palestine Action."

One protestor was seen with blood streaming down his face after they were arrested at the rally. While another protestor could be heard screaming that the police had hurt his back during their arrest. 

Before the protest, organisers were seen handing out pens, pieces of cardboard and legal advice to participants, before they sat down at 1PM in parliament square. 

Officers from City of London Police, Wales Police and Suffolk Police could be seen assisting the Metropolitan Police's operation on Saturday. 

Among the group of people detained by the police included scores of elderly protestors and families of Holocaust survivors who sat silently on the green in Parliament Square. 

Steve Masters, a British army veteran, was arrested by Metropolitan Police for holding a paper sign in support of Palestine Action and was carried away by officers after being removed from his wheelchair.

Before his arrest, he told Middle East Eye that he joined the protests after witnessing the "depressing scenes unfolding in Gaza."

"I served in the Royal Air Force for 19 years. I feel its important to be here because, whether or not you agree with the tactics of Palestine Action and others - the reality is that our government is complicit in genocide at the highest level," Masters told Middle East Eye. 

"Coming here to oppose the proscription is the least I can do, compared to the sacrifices being made by the people of Gaza and by those taking direct action with Palestine Action."

The London Metropolitan Police on X said the police at 5PM had arrested 150 people so far, adding that officers had been subjected to an â€œexceptional level of abuse including punches, kicks, spitting and objects being thrown, in addition to verbal abuseâ€.

â€œAny assaults against officers will not be tolerated and arrests have already been made,â€ they added in a post on X. â€œWe will identify all those responsible and prosecute to the full extent of the law.â€

Defend Our Juries (DOJ), which has staged regular protests since the government moved to proscribe Palestine Action in July, told protesters who signed up for Saturdayâ€™s demonstration to withhold their details from officers to force mass processing at police stations.

The group had scheduled a press conference on Tuesday to announce that an estimated 1,500 people were going to risk arrest under the Terrorism Act for holding signs reading, â€œI oppose genocide. I support Palestine Action.â€

But the conference was postponed after seven of its key speakers, including former government lawyer Tim Crosland, were arrested under section 12 of the Terrorism Act 2000. DOJ said arrestees had been held over the custody time limit of 24 hours and had their homes raided.

On Thursday, the Home Office won a legal decision to challenge the decision to grant a judicial review of Palestine Action's proscription under terror legislation that was due to be held in November. 

Israel's genocide in Gaza
Katherine Hearst
Ava Warriner

title: Six Palestinians die of starvation in Gaza in 24 hours
summary:
Six Palestinians die of starvation in Gaza in 24 hours

Six Palestinians, including a child, died in the past 24 hours from starvation and malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, Wafa news agency reported, citing medical sources.

The deaths bring the total number of starvation-related fatalities in the enclave to 382, including 135 children, the agency said.

title: Israeli forces open fire in West Bank town of Beit Fajjar
summary:
Israeli forces open fire in West Bank town of Beit Fajjar

Sources told Al Jazeera Arabic Israeli forces opened fire during a raid on the town of Beit Fajjar, south of Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank.

The escalation comes as the war on Gaza, ongoing since October 2023, has killed more than 64,000 Palestinians and injured over 161,000, most of them women and children.

title: One child killed every hour in Gaza war: Save the Children
summary:
One child killed every hour in Gaza war: Save the Children

Save the Children says that on average at least one Palestinian child has been killed every hour in Gaza during nearly 23 months of war.

Figures from Gaza authorities show more than 20,000 children â€“ about two percent of the territoryâ€™s child population â€“ have been killed since October 2023. Among them are at least 1,009 babies under the age of one, with nearly half born and killed during the war.

â€œThis is a shameful statistic â€“ a horrific new low in a war characterised by a constant stream of them,â€ said Ahmad Alhendawi, Save the Childrenâ€™s regional director for the Middle East, North Africa and Eastern Europe.

â€œWorst of all, we saw this coming. Systematic attacks on childrenâ€™s homes, playgrounds, schools and hospitals, starvation by design â€“ the world is doing nothing to stop it.â€
